utterances: Oh, yes.

I even told them when I wasn't going to go we could use the money for more important things and I wouldn't be going because it seemed like a pointless - they're talking about downsizing and things, and I'm like, well, why don't you, instead of downsizing us, not fly our team, you know, to the corporate headquarters and put us in hotels.
Yeah, but now you're not a team player.
You're somebody who's suspicious all of a sudden.
Yes, I am.
I am not a team player.
Sounds like you should be the CEO of the company, Jennifer.
You should be running things there.
Maybe, well okay.
Thanks.
Okay.
We can agree on that.
Thank you.
Okay.
Thanks for the call, Jennifer.
Bye.
So long.
Let's see if we can go to Neil.
Neil's with us from Troy, Michigan.
Hi.
How are you doing today?
Very well, thanks.

O'NEILL: Among those who did that, he says, Ronald Reagan, who, by the way, when he was still an actor, lent his voice to this ad by one of Medicare's biggest opponents - the American Medical Association.
Well long-time listener, first-time caller.
I, first of all, want to call in and defend Mr. Rogers.
I am 33 years old.
I grew up watching a lot of it.
I also happen to be a soccer coach for my daughter, who is six.
I coach six- and seven-year-olds.
And I know the value firsthand of reinforcing self-esteem.
And I agree with the author when he just said at the very end that, you know, the most important thing is moderation.
Because too little self-esteem and obviously people have problems, and too much they also have problems.
But, you know, knowing when to set limits, like everything else, really plays an important role.

Well, you know, the soccer issue is interesting, because nowadays there are some soccer leagues when they don't even keep score because they don't want the kids to feel that they're losers and the kids are keeping score in their heads.
Six and seven we don't keep scores as well.
You do not keep scores?
That's right?
Yeah.
Why not?
It seems to me, like, you know, in life we keep score in a lot of ways.
Why not let the kids learn that?
Well, you know, it's funny.
It's the kids themselves who want to keep score, and they often do despite our best efforts to try to sort of sweep that under the rug.
And I think that keeping score is really not the point, because we're out there doing skill development.
We want kids to have exercise and we want them to have fun.
And, you know, keeping score is great for older kids.
I'm one of the most competitive individuals that I know on an individual level.
But at this level I think that you're not really enforcing anything but competition, and there will be plenty of time for that when they get into their middle school years.
If you're not keeping scores, does it make sense to have a goalie?
Oh, sure.
I mean, that's - just because you don't keep track of your goals doesn't mean it's not important to go after them.
You know, if I have to say I really want to get a great job this year, would it be important that I set the bar at $60,000 a year, or $70,000.
As long as I'm happy with my performance in achieving that great job, you know, that's really the key.
All right.
I would call that - oh, you know, I appreciate how you explained that, but I would call it a little bit too much coddling.
I'm about to send my oldest daughter out into the, you know, she's going to college.
She will soon be in the workforce.
And, you know, I want her to know what the real world is like out there.
Your daughter is seven, you say?
My daughter is six, and I also have an eight-year-old and a three-year-old.
Okay.
But the six-year-old and the eight-year-old, they're the ones in soccer?
Only my six-year-old likes soccer.
Okay.
Yeah.
And I think that's really the key is making them happy with their results, you know.
If your daughter made, you know, $25,000 a year with her first job, would that be enough to take $45,000, I mean, at what level?
Isn't it really what she is happy with, even if she ended up, you know, not becoming the lawyer or the doctor that she wanted to be.
If she became an artist or a teacher who struggled but who made end meet, wouldn't that be enough?
Yeah, but, you know, if she turns out to be a lawyer, there's going to be a jury there and she's going to get a verdict one way or the other.
They do keep score.
Well, they keep score.
And like I said, I don't think that you need to never keep score.
Certainly there are times when, you know, it's very important to keep score.
I do Web development work myself and I do very deadline-driven, work that things either work or they don't work.
You can't hide or you shouldn't hide kids from those types of real-world ramifications.
All right, Neil.
Thanks very much for the call, and we wish your daughter the best of luck in her league.
My pleasure.
Thank you.
All right.
We're talking with Jeffrey Zaslow of the Wall Street Journal about his article, ""The Most-Praised Generation Goes to Work."" You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And let's get Charlotte on the line.
Charlotte with us from San Antonio.
Hi.
Hi.

I would just saying that I work for Wachovia, a large bank, and one of the things that I know that we do - our managers can walk up to us at any point in the day and give us a gift certificate for Outback Steakhouse or a Starbucks gift card, which I have received, personally.
I'm probably one of the younger callers; I'm 25.
Mm-hmm.
And I find it to be somewhat a - it's a gift to me because one of the things that some of us feel in our workforce is that we're not getting paid enough.
A lot of us, you know, we have those days where, you know, we're struggling to make ends meet.
And for somebody to walk over to me and give me a gift certificate so I can go out to dinner or something like that, that's actually an extra pat on the back.

Especially in one case where I received the Outback Steakhouse gift because I had picked up a customer request that no one had else had picked up and I just kind of volunteered to pick it up, and my manager thought that was a good idea.
That's one thing.

And the other thing our company does is they allocate these big gift packs where they can, you know, do that thing where they give an Outback gift certificate or they give cash incentives on an annual basis to lower-level employees rather than giving those incentives to higher-level employees, such as executive level.
Oh, I suspect those higher-level employees might get some bonuses every year, too.
But does this seem to be, though, a reward for something - you went out of your way to do something nice.
It was a reward for something you did that was good.
Exactly.
And I think that's what - a lot of companies are trying to do that, but I can also understand where they're just doing it because they're afraid of losing employees.
I can see that on both ends with my company, but I do see that - the main thing is compensation.
A lot of people don't really feel that they're getting paid what they're worth.
A lot of companies know that they're not paying people what they're worth.
I mean, because you can't place value on a person.
You can only place value on the amount of work that you think that they do.
Well, I think it's okay to a degree, but they say - when I talked to some experts that were looking into this, they say that these incentives can become entitlements.
And then everybody's getting - you know, Outback is crowded with these praised people and everybody still complains at work that maybe they got the Outback certificate for not such great work.
And in there heart of hearts they might know it.
And I'm not sure, you know, you want to pay a person an honest wage for a good job, but I'm not sure if these praise certificates are always the way to go.
All right.
Good luck, Charlotte.
And have a nice meal.
All right, thank you.
Bye-bye.
This is Marga(ph) from our blog.
I conduct management training sessions.
One of my favorite questions is to ask participants to raise their hand if they feel they get too much feedback on their job performance.
Typically, nobody raises their hand.
People are craving to know how well they're doing.
It's our responsibility to be specific about how they doing so they can keep performance on track or get it back on track.
And in a follow-up article that was really a conclusion you came from: They ought to get real feedback, criticism as well as praise, when merited.
